did.abstract: Conrad Woelfel (1902-1989) was a German American labor leader and fraternal organizer based in Detroit and New York City. Woelfel was born in Nuremberg, Germany and emigrated to the United States in 1923. He held various labor-related positions during his life: President of Engravers Lodge 2136; an Executive Board member of District 15, Machinists Union; and for 20 years, an organizer and Secretary-Treasurer of the International Metal Engravers Union. Woelfel was also deeply engaged in the German American community, co-founding the German-American Congress for Democracy (an organization for which he served as National Secretary). He held the position of President of the Workmen's Benefit Fund for 20 years, until his retirement in 1976. The Conrad Woelfel Papers (dated 1924-2008) includes scrapbooks, correspondence, newspaper articles, and photographs documenting Woelfel's labor union organizing in New York City from the 1930s through the 1970s. The collection also contains a small amount of materials documenting the Recreation Farm Society collected by Woelfel's daughter Helen Krump. Materials in the collection show the ways in which German immigrants navigated concepts of American patriotism during World War II, and how they built solidarity, community, and support for one another.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Conrad Woelfel Papers (dated 1924-2008) include scrapbooks, correspondence, newspaper articles, and photographs documenting Woelfel's labor union organizing in New York City from the 1930s through the 1970s, particularly his tenure as President of the Workman's Benefit Fund; and his engagement with the German American community, with an emphasis on his involvement with the German-American Congress for Democracy. The collection documents 20th century labor organizing, particularly in the greater New York City area and with an emphasis on the experiences of German and Jewish immigrants. The collection also shows the ways in which German immigrants navigated concepts of American patriotism during World War II, and how they built solidarity, community, and support for one another. Also included is a small amount of personal materials, such as family photographs, personal correspondence, a page from Woelfel's German passport, Woelfel's writing, and German newspapers. The collection also contains a small amount of materials documenting the Recreation Farm Society, which was connected to the Workman's Benefit Fund through the Women's Auxiliary. These materials, which include clippings, correspondence, and photographs, were collected by Woelfel's daughter Helen Krump.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Generally, this collection has been arranged chronologically, with personal materials first.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Marlene Hochman, President of the Toy Museum of New York, and Barbara Vivien, Board Member, in the memory of Helen Krump, Conrad Woelfel's daughter, in October 2020. The accession number associated with this gift is 2020.037.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders. Pages from scrapbooks were removed from their original binders and rehoused in folders in their existing order, noting which scrapbook they came from. The original binders have been discarded due to their size and condition. Materials were described on the collection-level with a box-level inventory.

At the time of processing, scrapbook pages were removed from non-archival sleeves and rehoused in archival paper sleeves and folders. Duplicate photographs, clippings, and financial documents were removed.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Conrad Woelfel (1902-1989) was a German American labor leader and fraternal organizer based in Detroit and New York City. Woelfel was born in Nuremberg, Germany and emigrated to the United States in 1923. He held various labor-related positions during his life: President of Engravers Lodge 2136; an Executive Board member of District 15, Machinists Union; and for 20 years, an organizer and Secretary-Treasurer of the International Metal Engravers Union. Woelfel was also deeply engaged in the German American community, co-founding the German-American Congress for Democracy (an organization for which he served as National Secretary). He held the position of President of the Workmen's Benefit Fund for 20 years, until his retirement in 1976. The Recreation Farm Society was part of the Women's Auxiliary of the Workmen's Benefit Fund; both Woelfel's wife, Betty, and daughter, Helen, were involved; Helen served as president in the late 1970s.
